>> My name is Ilana Weiss, and I work on the
Leadership Development Team as part of Google

3.text:
University.
And today, it is my pleasure to welcome Tim

7.text:
Brown to the "Authors at Google" series.
Tim Brown is the CEO and president of IDEO,

12.text:
a global design consultancy focused on creating
impact through design.

17.text:
IDEO has won more industrial design excellence
awards than any other firm, and has been ranked

22.text:
in the top 25 most innovative companies in
the world by BusinessWeek.

27.text:
Tim is an industrial designer by training.
And his own work has earned him numerous design

32.text:
awards, and has been exhibited at MOMA in
New York City, Axis Gallery in Tokyo, and

35.text:
the Design Museum in London.
He has participated in the World Economic

42.text:
Forum and the TED Conference.
Tim has led strategic client relationships

47.text:
with organizations such as Pepsi, Mayo Clinic,
Proctor & Gamble, and Steelcase.

53.text:
Many of us are here today because IDEO is
a company that we really admire.

56.text:
Innovation is a core value that drives what
we do here at Google, and who better to understand

60.text:
and also reflect that value than Tim?
We're also lucky here today, because we're

65.text:
among the first to hear about his new book,
hot off the presses last week, "Change by

71.text:
Design: How design thinking transforms organizations
and inspires innovation."

75.text: Please join me in welcoming Tim Brown.

81.text:
Tim Brown: Okay.
Well, thank you.

86.text:
It's great to be here.
It is great to be here.

90.text:
So, I'm going the talk for maybe 25 minutes
or so on what happens when we move from design

98.text:
to design thinking.
I'm going to start off with a little bit of

103.text:
autobiography.
And this rather lousy image is actually the

106.text:
first thing that I ever was hired to design
professionally.

110.text:
I wasn't even out of design school yet, actually.
And it's a woodworking machine, or at least,

114.text:
it's a piece of woodworking machine.
And I was hired to make it a little bit easier

120.text:
to use, a little bit more attractive, so that
this company could sell more spindle molders

127.text:
and wood saws and other machinery that many
of you may have used; I don't know.

133.text:
And, you know, I think I did a pretty good
job.

135.text:
In fact, if you happen to be on your vacation
in England, and happen to visit a woodworking

140.text:
shop, somewhere in the north of England, as
you may do -- I don't know.

144.text:
I do often -- you'll actually find these machines
still being used today.

147.text:
Unfortunately, you won't find the company
that makes them, because that went out of

151.text:
business, actually, quite soon after I'd done
my project.

155.text:
The next project that I did is a fax machine.
And, again, I was hired to put an attractive

160.text:
shell around some -- what was then -- relatively
new technology.

164.text:
And again, to make it a little bit more attractive
and easy to use.

168.text:
This is actually one of those things that
ended up in the design museums.

171.text:
But again, 18 months later, the product was
obsolete.

175.text:
And, of course, now the whole technology is
obsolete.

177.text:
My teenage daughters don't even know what
faxing is.

179.text:
Many of you may not either.
So, you know, it occurred to me that what

185.text:
passed the design maybe wasn't all that important.
You know, making things a bit easier to use,

190.text:
making them a bit more attractive, making
them a bit more marketable.

194.text:
By focusing on "a design," I was being kind
of incremental and not having very much impact.

201.text:
But I think this kind of small view of design
is a relatively recent phenomena, and actually,

206.text:
kind of emerged in the latter half of the
20th century as design became a tool of consumerism.

213.text:
So, when we talk about design today and, particularly,
when we read about it in the popular press,

218.text:
we're often talking about products like these.
Amusing? Yeah.

229.text:
But this wasn't always the way.
And I'd like to suggest that if we take a

236.text:
different view of design, and instead of focusing
on the products, focus on design thinking

243.text:
as a process, then design perhaps ends up
having a bigger impact.

250.text:
So, again, this is a bit of a Brit-themed
talk today.

252.text:
And I apologize, but that's where I come from,
as you may recognize from the accent.

257.text:
I don't know. Does anybody recognize this
guy?

259.text:
Not including the people who already watched
my TED poll.

264.text:
Okay, so this is, you know, perhaps the 19th
century equivalent of Larry Page and Sergey

270.text:
Brin.
This is where people wore more interesting

276.text:
But this is Kingdom Brunel, and he was a truly
great engineer, and I think, design thinker

283.text:
from the 19th century in Britain.
And he built many firsts, including the Clifton

288.text:
Suspension Bridge, one of the first suspension
bridges in Bristol.

292.text:
And the Thames Tunnel at Rotherhithe, one
of the then longest, underwater tunnels in

299.text:
the world.
His most famous creation in the south of England

305.text:
-- I grew up very close to it -- and it's
called the Great Western Railway.

309.text:
And, in fact, one of my favorite things to
do as a kid was to ride my bicycle along the

313.text:
edge of the railway line waiting for the big
express trains to roll past, much to the consternation

319.text:
of my mother.
You can see it represented here in JMW Turner's

323.text:
painting, "Rain, Steam and Speed."
What was remarkable about Brunel when he built

329.text:
this railway was that he wasn't just thinking
about, "How do I engineer a railway?"

333.text:
He said that what he wanted to achieve for
his passengers was the experience of floating

338.text:
across the countryside.
It's a really great way of thinking about

342.text:
building a railway.
And, in order to do that, he had to create

345.text:
the flattest gradients that had ever yet been
built.

350.text:
And that meant long viaducts over river valleys.
This one is actually over the river Thames,

355.text:
at Maidenhead, and long tunnels like the one
at Box in Wiltshire, but he didn't stop there.

361.text:
He didn't just stop with trying to make the
best railway journey he could.

365.text:
He imagined an integrated transportation system,
where it was possible to get on a train in

371.text:
London and get off a ship in New York.
One journey from London to New York.

380.text:
This is the S.S. Great Western that he built
to take care of the second half of that journey,

384.text:
one of the first transatlantic steamships.
So now, although this was a century before

389.text:
the emergence of design as a profession, I
really think that Brunel was using design

395.text:
thinking to come up with great innovations
and world-changing designs.

399.text:
And I'm going to talk a little bit about what
that is.

402.text:
Design thinking starts with what Roger Martin,
the University of Toronto Business School

407.text:
dean, calls "integrated thinking," this ability
to hold opposing constraints in one's head

413.text:
and, from that, get to new solutions.
In design, this means balancing desirability

420.text:
-- what people need and want -- with technical
feasibility and economic viability.

426.text:
And with breakthrough designs, like the Great
Western Railway, we often stretch that balance

431.text:
to the very limit and sometimes break it.
And I'm sure many of the things that you do

435.text:
do the same thing.
So, somehow we went from this to this.

442.text:
We went from systems' thinkers who were reinventing
the world around us to a priesthood of folks

449.text:
in black turtlenecks and designer glasses
working on small things.

455.text:
As design emerged as a profession, it focused
on a steadily smaller canvas, until it came

461.text:
to stand for fashion, aesthetics, and style.
And, you know, I have to admit -- I'm a fully

467.text:
paid member of that priesthood, and somewhere
my jacket has my own pair of designer glasses

472.text:
in it.
So, I'm throwing stones at myself, as well

475.text:
as my colleagues, in the design industry.
But, I think design is getting big again.

482.text:
And I think that's happening through the application
of design thinking to new kinds of problems:

490.text:
things like climate change, healthcare, clean
water, security, social welfare.

499.text:
And, as we see this reemergence of design
thinking as something that can have perhaps

503.text:
greater impact, then we can observe some basic
ideas that design thinking kind of operates

510.text:
through, and we can perhaps learn from it.
So, what I'd like to do is talk about a few

514.text:
of those for the next few minutes, and talk
about some of the kinds of projects and problems

518.text:
that they're being applied to.
So, now, design thinking starts with the idea

526.text:
of being human-centered.
It may integrate the constraints of technology

531.text:
and economics, but it begins with what people
need or might need: what makes life easier,

538.text:
more enjoyable, what makes technology useful
and usable.

542.text:
But this is more than simply good ergonomics,
putting the buttons in the right place, whether

547.text:
they're software buttons or hardware buttons.
It's often about understanding culture and

553.text:
context before we even know where to start
to have our ideas.

557.text:
So, when a team was working in India on a
new vision-screening program, they wanted

563.text:
to understand what motivated and excited these
kids, to understand how they might play a

568.text:
role in screening their parents.
Conversion Sound is a small start-up -- actually

576.text:
based here in the Bay Area -- that's developed
an ultra-low-cost, very high quality, digital

581.text:
hearing aid for developing markets.
Now, here in the West, these hearing aids

586.text:
are fitted by highly-trained technicians.
In places like India, those technicians simply

592.text:
don't exist.
And so, it took a team working with community

596.text:
health workers and patients to understand
how a PDA application might replace technicians

605.text:
in the diagnosis and fitting service.
But, again, the team -- instead of starting

611.text:
with technology -- the team started with people
and culture.

616.text:
And this idea of closely observing people
can lead to recognizing behaviors that can

623.text:
ultimately lead to breakthrough innovations.
So -- when a team was interested in studying

628.text:
families in the U.S. to see how they managed
their money, they saw two interesting behaviors.

633.text:
This is one of them.
They saw people who were rounding up their

637.text:
utility bills when they paid them.
And when they asked, "Well, why did you do

642.text:
that?"
The response was, "Well, I don't like to get

644.text:
behind.
I don't like to feel that I owe the utility

647.text:
company money."
And another behavior that they saw -- which

650.text:
is one that I think many of us exhibit -- was
that when people went and paid for a cash

654.text:
transaction, they would take the coins that
they got in exchange in change, and take them

659.text:
home, stick them in a jar or somewhere, and
then every so often, take those to the bank,

663.text:
or give them to the kids to take to the bank
and pay into their savings accounts.

666.text:
Again, when we asked them about this, this
is this idea of saving invisibly, saving without

672.text:
thinking about it.
So, that led to the idea of a new savings

677.text:
account for Bank of America called "Keep the
Change."

679.text:
I don't know if any of you use it.
And what happens here is that when you go

683.text:
and pay for a transaction with your debit
card, the payment gets rounded up to the nearest

688.text:
dollar, and the change gets put into your
savings account.

692.text:
So, it takes this kind of behavior of automatic
savings and staying ahead, and applies it

697.text:
to a very simple piece of technology to create
a new kind of service.

702.text:
Again, it started with recognizing a behavior
and led to an innovation.

707.text:
So, if design thinking starts with the idea
of being human-centered, then it moves quickly

713.text:
to learning by making things.
Instead of thinking of "what to build," we

719.text:
"build in order to think."
Because prototypes help us learn about our

724.text:
ideas, and, the faster we put our prototypes
out into the world, the faster we know about

730.text:
the qualities and strengths and weaknesses
of our ideas.

733.text:
The faster that we can evolve them, the faster
we can improve them.

738.text:
Now, a lot has been said about the Aravind
Eye Clinic in Madurai, India.

742.text:
I'm sure many of you have heard of it.
It manages to serve vast quantities of very

748.text:
poor patients by taking the revenues from
those patients that can afford to pay, and

753.text:
using them to cross-subsidize those who cannot.
They're an incredibly efficient organization,

761.text:
but they're also very innovative.
And the thing that I noticed when I visited

767.text:
was this willingness to prototype new ideas
very quickly.

771.text:
So, this is the manufacturing facility for
one of their biggest cost breakthroughs.

776.text:
It's actually where they manufacture the intraocular
lenses that they use to replace damaged lenses

784.text:
-- our own lenses that are damaged by cataracts.
And by doing this, they brought the cost down

789.text:
from $200 a pair, when they're made by western
producers, to just $4 a pair.

795.text:
That's a huge, huge cost savings.
And the way they did this was, I think, through

800.text:
a prototyping approach.
Instead of building some fancy, new factory,

805.text:
they put the facility in the basement of one
of their hospitals.

808.text:
Instead of using the fancy, large-scale machines
that western producers use, they use low-cost,

813.text:
CAD/CAM technology to produce their lenses.
And they're now the biggest manufacturer of

818.text:
these lenses in the developing world, and
actually, they just recently moved into a

824.text:
custom factory.
So, if human need is the place to start and

829.text:
prototyping a vehicle for progress, then there
are also questions to be asked about the destination.

835.text:
Instead of seeing consumption as its primary
goal, design thinking is beginning to explore

840.text:
the idea and potential of participation.
The shift from a passive relationship between

847.text:
consumer and producer to the active engagement
of everyone in experiences that are meaningful,

854.text:
productive, and profitable.
And clearly, a lot of this capacity to explore

862.text:
more participative experiences has been driven
by the web and many of the things that you

867.text:
all work on.
Another Brit, my apologies.

870.text:
You're getting a great British history lesson
today.

874.text:
When Sir William Beveridge created the first
of his famous reports in 1942, he proposed

879.text:
what became Britain's welfare state, in which
he hoped that every citizen would be an active

886.text:
participant in their own social welfare.
By the time he wrote his third report, he

892.text:
confessed that he had failed, and instead
created a society of welfare consumers.

902.text:
Hillary Cottam, Charlie Ledbetter, and Hugo
Manassei of Participle in England have taken

908.text:
this idea of participation and, in their manifesto
entitled "Beveridge 4.0," they've described

914.text:
a model for reinventing the welfare state.
One of their projects is this one.

919.text:
It's called Southwark Circle, in which a small
team of designers worked with local residents

924.text:
in Southern, South London to develop a new
membership organization that helps the elderly

930.text:
with household tasks.
Ideas were developed and refined with 150

936.text:
elderly people and their families, before
the service was launched earlier this year.

942.text:
And the service itself is a combination of
"Can a for-profit like activities and volunteer

947.text:
activities," and it's really an idea about
taking a lot of what currently is the responsibility

952.text:
of the healthcare providers and social workers
providers, and bring it back out into the

956.text:
community where it can be done a lot less
expensively and often to a higher quality.

963.text:
And, you know, I think that this idea of designing
participatory systems where value -- over

970.text:
and above cash -- is both generated and measured,
isn't only going to be a major theme for design

976.text:
as we go forward, but perhaps a major theme
for our economy as a whole.

981.text:
And we can take this idea of participation
to its logical conclusion and say that perhaps

987.text:
the way that design can have its greatest
impact is if we take it out of the hands of

992.text:
designers and put it into the hands of everyone.
So, a team of nurses and practitioners at

998.text:
Kaiser Permanente, a local organization, tackled
the problem of improving the patient experience.

1004.text:
And one thing they focused on was the exchange
of knowledge between nurses.

1009.text:
In particular, one particular project was
how they changed shift.

1015.text:
And so, based on a process of observation,
brainstorming new ideas, and rapid prototyping,

1020.text:
the team developed a completely new way of
changing shift.

1023.text:
And instead of retreating to the nurse's station
to share and tell each other about the various

1029.text:
states and needs of patients, they developed
a method for changing shift on the ward in

1035.text:
front of patients using a simple software
tool.

1038.text:
The innovation brought the time that nurses
are away from patients down from 40 minutes

1043.text:
on average to just 12 minutes on average,
increased patient confidence because now they

1048.text:
know what's going on, and increased nurse
happiness.

1053.text:
And you multiply that savings by every nurse
on every shift on every ward in the 35 hospitals

1059.text:
that Kaiser has in their system and that results
in a lot more nursing time.

1064.text:
And I think this is just one example of thousands
of opportunities there are in healthcare alone

1071.text:
to create innovations if we can get these
kinds of processes into the hands of the people

1075.text:
that are actually providing the service.
But, unfortunately, good ideas don't sell

1085.text:
themselves.
Any fans of Madmen might recognize the image

1088.text:
in the background.
The 20th century saw the rise of an industry

1093.text:
built to tell stories to encourage us to consume
more -- the advertising industry.

1101.text:
And yet, when the goal is to create consumption
but not participation, stories aren't sufficient;

1106.text:
we need movements.
One example of that, I think, is this one.

1113.text:
It's not every day that you get the prime
minister of a G-8 country to launch your campaign,

1118.text:
but that's exactly what a team of Japanese
Creative Agency Hakuhodo did when they launched

1125.text:
this idea called Cool Biz.
Have any of you heard of Cool Biz?

1128.text:
It's a great idea.
So, this was the, then, prime minister Koizumi

1135.text:
of Japan.
And the idea of Cool Biz was, in order to

1138.text:
try to bring down the carbon footprint of
Japan, they wanted to be able to lower the

1143.text:
-- or raise, I guess -- the temperature settings
on the air-conditioning systems in offices

1149.text:
during the summer.
One of the biggest things that was preventing

1153.text:
this was the formal dress that Japanese businessmen
wear.

1156.text:
You guys wouldn't have a problem with this.
But, all Japanese businessmen would turn up

1160.text:
in a suit and tie all the way through the
summer.

1164.text:
And so, the idea was that, "If we could persuade
Japanese businessmen not to wear a tie, we

1169.text:
could raise the temperature on the thermometers
and save gigatons of carbon, or whatever it

1174.text:
is."
So, how do you persuade very conservative

1180.text:
Japanese businessmen to stop wearing a tie?
Well, the way they did it was, they had a

1184.text:
bunch of Japanese fashion designers design
a whole range of new clothing, and then they

1188.text:
had all of the CEOs and the prime minister
 -- all of the CEOs of the major corporations

1192.text:
in Japan -- do a fashion show with all of
this new clothing.

1195.text:
So, that was one thing they did.
The second thing they did as part of this

1199.text:
campaign, they got these cool, little badges,
and any company that signed up for the Cool

1203.text:
Biz Campaign, if you were wearing one of these
badges, you simply couldn't tell somebody

1207.text:
that they were wearing inappropriate dress
at work.

1210.text:
So now, again, in California, we don't need
badges for that, but in Japan, they needed

1214.text:
badges for it.
But, this movement has ended up with thousands

1218.text:
of companies in Japan signing up for the Cool
Biz Campaign, and you know a lot of carbon

1226.text:
is being saved as a result.
They have a similar program in -- oh, one

1231.text:
of the other downsides, by the way, of having
the temperature set so low in offices was,

1238.text:
you'd see most of the Japanese women, who
were also formally dressed in skirts and jackets,

1244.text:
in the offices with blankets over their knees,
because they were freezing cold.

1248.text:
So, it had another kind of comfort advantage
benefit to women.

1252.text:
And there's a similar program that goes on
in the winter called Warm Biz. Same thing.

1256.text:
"Wear a woolly sweater to work, and we can
lower the setting on the thermostat."

1263.text:
So an example of, I think -- of going from
the idea of just telling a story to creating

1269.text:
a movement -- in a similar vein, we've been
working on a project for the International

1273.text:
Campaign Against Unwanted Pregnancy.
And, you know, there's some kind of interesting

1279.text:
statistics.
Six out of ten pregnancies to women in the

1283.text:
20 to 24 range are unplanned and unwanted.
And the goal of the project was to reduce

1291.text:
this unplanned pregnancy amongst unmarried
adults.

1294.text:
Now, the core of this is a website with lots
of services on it.

1298.text:
This is just one, helping people select various
forms of contraception.

1302.text:
Some don't come highly recommended, like champagne
corks perhaps.

1305.text:
[laughter]
I think there's a piece of string somewhere.

1308.text:
I'm not sure what you are supposed to use
that for.

1312.text:
But, anyway, sounds very painful.
But the service is only going to work if we

1319.text:
kind of get people to engage with it.
So a couple of parts of that, there was this

1325.text:
whole series of posters rather insulting to
the parenting capabilities of young men.

1332.text:
And then, this one -- which is a little hard
to tell from this image, but, it'll be a bit

1336.text:
more obvious for the next one when you see
the prototype.

1338.text:
This is a sticker that goes on a mirror in
the women's bathroom, women's restroom, and

1344.text:
that's the sticker.
That's the sticker.

1347.text:
So when you walk into the bathroom, you can
get this rather [laughter] uncomfortable view

1353.text:
about what it might be like should you decide,
or not decide, to do something.

1359.text:
So again, you know, I mean it's the idea of
using design to get people to engage with

1367.text:
things a little bit more than they might otherwise.
So, these are just some of the approaches

1373.text:
that design thinking takes and some of the
kinds of projects that it's being applied

1376.text:
to.
But I like to go back to Brunel here, and

1381.text:
propose a possible connection as to why this
is happening now, why it didn't happen 20

1385.text:
years ago, and why design thinking may be
a useful tool.

1390.text:
And I think that connection is a pretty simple
one; it's to do with change.

1395.text:
In times of great change, we demand new solutions,
new alternatives, things that haven't existed

1402.text:
before.
It's a very simple idea.

1403.text:
You know, Brunel worked during the height
of the Industrial Revolution, when every piece

1408.text:
of our economy and society was getting reinvented.
Now, you know, many of those industrial systems

1416.text:
from Brunel's time have run their course and,
indeed, they're part of the problem today

1419.text:
in many cases.
And again, we live in the midst of massive

1423.text:
change; it's just a different kind of change,
driven by different kinds of technology.

1429.text:
And that change is forcing us to question
many of the fundamental components of our

1434.text:
society, like healthcare, government, education,
and security.

1438.text:
And, in periods of change, we need new ideas,
because our existing solutions are simply

1443.text:
becoming obsolete because of that change.
It's a very simple idea.

1447.text:
But, why design thinking?
Because it changes the way that we tackle

1452.text:
problems.
Instead of focusing on our -- sort of, defaulting

1456.text:
to -- our normal convergent approach where
we make the best choice out of existing alternatives,

1464.text:
it encourages us to diverge, to explore new
ideas, and create new alternatives that haven't

1470.text:
existed before.
But, before we can do that, before we can

1475.text:
diverge, before we can explore new alternatives,
there's an important first step.

1482.text:
And that first step is, "What's the question
we're trying to answer?"

1486.text:
In the design industry, we might call that,
"What's the design brief?"

1489.text:
Now, Brunel may have asked this question,
"How to I take a train from London to New

1493.text:
York?"
He'd have had a hard time building a bridge,

1496.text:
but he did come up with a solution.
But, what are the kinds of questions that

1501.text:
we might be tackling today?
And, we're very lucky we get asked -- just

1505.text:
as you are.
We're very lucky we get asked lots of really

1508.text:
fascinating questions.
We get to ask lots of fascinating questions

1511.text:
ourselves.
These are just some of them we've been working

1513.text:
on recently.
I won't be very long, so don't worry.

1518.text:
One of them, in particular, is a project that
we've been doing with The Acumen Fund, which
